Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Particle-by-Particle Studies of Heterogeneous Dynamics in Molecular and Colloidal Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Laura Kaufman of Columbia University, her postdoctoral fellows and graduate and undergraduate students are addressing fundamental aspects of heterogeneous behavior in systems in which the dynamics are strongly affected by either steric or electrostatic crowding. Small molecule glass formers, simulated model glassy liquids, and low volume fraction colloidal glasses and gels are being investigated. The heterogeneous dynamics, local properties, and cooperative rearrangements of these systems are being interrogated via three techniques that avoid ensemble averaging. These techniques are single molecule (SM) fluorescence measurements, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, and coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) microscopy. The SM microscopy and MD simulations will clarify (1) if and how probe properties affect measured probe dynamics, (2) how these same properties potentially affect host dynamics and heterogeneities, and (3) how probe bearing experiments can report a length scale of heterogeneity in glassy systems. CARS imaging will be performed on low volume fraction colloidal glasses and gels. Here, the Kaufman group is investigating whether the dynamics of formation and relaxation of these systems exhibit the same sort of heterogeneous behavior and cooperative rearrangements that have been seen in high particle density glassy environments.

Because all condensed phase systems display dynamics affected by crowding in some way, studying these effects in the systems most obviously impacted increases fundamental understanding of condensed phase chemistry. Understanding glassy dynamics, and the prevention of crystallization, is also important in diverse applications from petroleum transportation to cryopreservation of cells. Aside from the broader scientific impacts of this work, Professor Kaufman is presenting lectures on complex fluids to local elementary school students. Professor Kaufman continues to identify and mentor especially promising science students at Columbia University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project addressed fundamental aspects of systems in which the motion of the particles the system comprises are strongly affected by crowding.  Such systems include not only liquids, gels, and glasses but also biologically complex environments such as the cytoplasm of cells. The project focused primarily on a class of materials known as supercooled liquids. These are liquids that have been cooled below their freezing temperature without experiencing a phase transition into a crystalline solid. This can be achieved in principle by cooling any liquid sufficiently quickly.

Supercooled liquids look like liquids, in that they are amorphous and display no signs of long range order. However, they are distinct from normal liquids in that the molecules within them move slowly: indeed, molecular motion in supercooled liquids slows abruptly as temperature decreases, a property that is not well understood. Supercooled liquids display other poorly understood behaviors as well. Chief among these is a property termed “dynamic heterogeneity” or “spatially heterogeneous dynamics.” Dynamic heterogeneity, whose presence has been suggested by many experiments and simulations, describes the situation in which small regions within a system display dynamics that are different from those in neighboring regions. These distinct environments are not static, but instead randomize over some time, with experimental results to date strongly disagreeing on this randomization time. The spatially heterogeneous dynamics that characterize molecular behavior in supercooled liquids is all the more surprising because it is present in the absence of any clear structural heterogeneity in these systems. Taken together, the questions surrounding the motion of particles in supercooled liquids represent one of the greatest mysteries of condensed phase science.

Because supercooled liquids are expected display spatially heterogeneous dynamics, interrogating large sets of molecules simultaneously is likely to average over all the environments of interest, precluding direct interrogation of the length and time scales of interest. This encourages the use of single molecule approaches. Here, small fluorescent probe molecules are embedded dilutely in the host supercooled liquids, and the rotational dynamics of the probe molecules is monitored under the assumption that the probe dynamics reflect local dynamics of the host around the probe. This assumption needed validation since the probe molecules used in these studies are rather large, and may thus either alter or average over heterogeneities in the host supercooled liquid. To substantiate this assumption, we systematically varied probe size in several molecular supercooled liquids. One key finding was that all probes employed did report dynamic heterogeneity present in the host. Beyond that, however, it was found that the probes that rotated most quickly reported the greatest degree of heterogeneity. This allowed us to set bounds on the length and time scales of heterogeneities in these molecular supercooled liquids.  The heterogeneities are larger than the < 1nm differences in size between the different probes employed, and the time that a particular dynamic environment exists spans a range that centered near the structural relaxation time of the supercooled liquid. Simulations were undertaken to complement our experiments. For example, we used molecular dynamics to simulate probes embedded in supercooled liquids to understand how probes may alter the heterogeneity of the surroundings (for typically sized probes, it does not) and may affect the reporting of these dynamics (for typically sized probes, it may).
